issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

fields.description: [Address Sanitizer|https://github.com/google/sanitizers/wiki/AddressSanitizer] might be a better alternative to valgrind in clang or gcc builds. As part of this, we should also document how users can run their own local ASAN builds
fields.summary: [C++] Run ASAN builds in Travis CI

comments.body: We are using clang in our builds now. Any objections to switching to ASAN from valgrind?
If we do that, we should probably have a nightly build at some point that checks with valgrind, too
Having ASAN in PR builds and valgrind in nightlies sounds fine. ASAN is much faster but I still have the feeling that valgrind highlights a bit more memory issues.

According to [AddressSanitizerComparisonOfMemoryTools|https://github.com/google/sanitizers/wiki/AddressSanitizerComparisonOfMemoryTools], ASAN won't detect reads of uninitialized memory, unlike Valgrind. Such detection can be done by [Memory Sanitizer|https://github.com/google/sanitizers/wiki/MemorySanitizer], which unfortunately requires rebuilding all dependencies including libstdc++.

I see. Valgrind is pretty useful, then. We might want to see if there's a way to opt in to valgrind (using {{[valgrind]}} or some tag in commit messages) if we decide to cut build times by turning off valgrind by default

Note the current testing duration with Valgrind is 3 minutes, which isn't enormous either:
https://travis-ci.org/apache/arrow/jobs/412563130#L2044
The {{PLASMA_VALGRIND=1}} option has a significant impact also

I'd estimate we spend 1-2 minutes in {{test_plasma.py}} indeed:
[https://travis-ci.org/apache/arrow/jobs/412563130#L9303]
